ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Watched/read so much new horror media!! Loved that.
I developed skills in analyzing horror films and horror literature, in adapting horror commentary to an argument, and in implementing horror techniques into my creative writing.
Multiple. I was able to take something that I have had a lifelong personal interest in and consider it in an academic way.
I left with a better appreciation of the horror genre, including its function and aesthetics and its tropes. I also left with better confidence as a writer.

I not only learned a ton about horror and the horror genre across different mediums such as film and literature, but also developed my creative and analytic writing in new ways and really improved as an overall writer.

This was my first creative writing course at Yale, and while it was certainly challenging I am grateful for the opportunity to build and improve my writing skills. I learned how to write short stories and also improved my skills in analytical writing.

I am not a strong writer, but I was able to delve into literature again after taking a hiatus since highschool. It was great to be able to discuss the messages of stories and how horror adds to these messages. I learned how to analyze horror films rather than watch passively as I used to. I wish my creative skills were a little better, but this was the only course I have ever taken including high school that assigned a creative fiction portion that was fun to plan out (though stressful to write and actualize).

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Would have liked to have read more theory. The discussions sometimes felt ungrounded, and if we had engaged with more analytical/theoretical/art crit type texts I might have been able to think abt what I was reading or watching more deeply. But I absolutely loved the things we did discuss and Deming is a great Professor! Loved the chance to do a creative project!

Strengths professor Deming is the best part of the course. He was very engaging and invited various contemporary horror directors and authors to the class for us to meet with. The variety of assignments and the class dynamic really facilitated learning.
We were able to speak to many horror creators, which was both exciting and insightful.

The class was just awesome! I loved having a critical and creative assignment to complete. I loved the in-class writing exercises and the how Deming made sharing low-stakes. I loved our guest speakers.
The only weakness was it being over zoom, as I wish we could've enjoyed this class in person. There was nothing that could be done about that though1

This was a phenomenal course, and I struggle to think of ways it could be improved. The texts and films chosen in the syllabus were excellent and allowed for fruitful seminar discussions.  Important topics concerning race, gender, politics, etc. were discussed in relation to the horror genre and discussions were genuinely very engaging.

Loved the guests we had, and also our little google folder. I got very close with many of my classmates outside of class and bonded through reviewing each other's work, etc. The professor is very entertaining and despite the spring and COVID slump, he still engaged us and I think everyone had a good time doing the work as well. I don't think there is anything I would necessarily add, other than maybe a checkpoint for the midterm and final for the professor, but that's a lot of work to put on one person so the peer reviews are definitely more than enough (maybe do 2 sessions for the students, one to brainstorm and one to edit).

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was extremely well-adjusted to COVID.
I appreciated how the reading response requirement was reduced and meeting the speakers over Zoom.

Learning over zoom for me was really difficult, but Professor Deming made it the best it possibly could be by still having us engage in in-class writing  exercises and having us share our work with each other and still having us meet virtually to workshop each other's work.
We were able to host a number of guest speakers due to the virtual format, which was very successful and engaging.

It's funny to say that I'm sure it was a little awkward at first, but throughout the semester I think everyone got more comfortable and it feels like we were all together in person. Of course being a small, live seminar class helped, but in general we weren't overwhelmed with work form this class and each assignment was enjoyable.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Deming is a great writing teacher.
Absolutely. The material is fascinating and covered in a clear, enlightening way.

I would recommend this course to any student curious about horror or eager to engage with popular media. Theres film and literature on the syllabus, space for students of all writing abilities to engage, and its a fun classroom environment that has workshop elements without the anxiety.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student, especially anyone interested in the horror/thriller genre. The works we read and watched were engaging and entertaining and a lot of times didn't even feel like work, and Professor Deming is incredible and will really help anyone improve as a writer.

I simply cannot recommend this course enough! I don't have words to express how great this course is  if you are at all interested in horror, in any form (film, TV, books, short stories, etc.) I urge you to take this class. I had no prior experience in creative writing and my skill set is far from that of an English major, and yet I enjoyed this class and would say that it is one of the best I have taken at Yale, in any subject/department. You get to explore your passions and write about whatever you want, in an incredibly supportive and engaging environment. I was so glad to have this opportunity to push myself and go out of my comfort zone: creative writing has always been frightening and challenging for me, but I was able to overcome that fear in this class. If you are even vaguely thinking about taking this course, do it!
Hands (or hooks) down, this class is a real gem for anyone into horror or even taboos in literature.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We learned by reading, speaking with guest authors, writing creatively and critically.
We only had a virtual seminar.
This course also included live virtual office hours.
We also interview guest speakers, whose books an works we consumed!
